item.title: The stack monoid
item.description: This is a bit of a followup to Towards GPGPU JSON parsing. That proposed a rather roundabout way to parallelize a simple parsing task. Having had more GPU programming experience under my belt, I don‚Äôt expect that particular approach to work well, but it did suggest that parallelism exists in the problem.

item.description: The Ergodox EZ plays a big part of my day-to-day productivity and managing chronic pain. Since the keyboard has an ortholinear layout, it requires relearning of how to type.

item.title: Building a better home network
item.description: I finally got my home network in a place where I am happy with it. I wanted to share my setup and what I learned about it. There has never been a better time to set up a great home network; there are several new tools that have made this easier and better than in the past. Hopefully this will help you set up your home network!

item.title: Fraidycat
item.description: Long-time readers will know that I‚Äôm a big fan of RSS feeds. An RSS reader has been essential to my web experience since I first came online, and I‚Äôve doggedly stuck to using them even as the web has centralised onto a few platforms and much digital ink spilt about the ‚Äúdeath of RSS‚Äù. Luckily, I‚Äôm not the only one who prefers this old-school, human-curated approach to the web over today‚Äôs platforms and their algorithms.

item.title: When to stop working on side-projects
item.description: I‚Äôm a professional coder, and so like all good coders‚Ñ¢, I spend a non-trivial number of hours working each week on side-projects. The projects‚Äô range is pretty wide, from low-level RPC stuff to machine learning and rendering engines. Right now, I‚Äôm working on several projects that might never see the light-of-day. The most significant among them (and the only one that has been open-sourced) is Shadesmar.

item.title: Key exchange standards - Manning
item.description: From Real-World Cryptography by David Wong In this article, the author teaches readers about the Diffie-Hellman key exchange standard, which was the very first key exchange algorithm ever invented, and the Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman key exchange standard, which is the Diffie-Hellman built with elliptic curves.
